children.subject: W chain

I opened a 6 yo wine bottle just for this.  


So glad I spent three years here not taking this class. Now I might even graduate early with  Fall as my non-enrolled EGT if I want.

EECS 16B will count toward your 120 overall units needed to graduate. 

Taking Math 53 reduced the upper div tech elective units from 7 to 4. Now, you don't need to take Math 53 in order to have them reduced. You only need to take 1 4-unit tech elective. If Data 104 is 4 units, then that's all you would need.

Math 53 would also count toward your 120 units.

<md>If I've already taken EECS16B, does it count towards anything in my major?

Is it also correct to assume the changing of 7 to 4 units of technical elective is just an official phasing out of math 53's role in the CS degree (i.e. I've already taken math 53 and was planning to take data 104 for my 7 units of technical elective. Now that it's just 4 units, data 104 will serve for this coverage?).

If we have already taken math 53, does it give us any help anywhere else?</md>
<md>You can still take Math 53 if you want to; no one is stopping you from enrolling in it. </md>
You could look at HKN reviews to see how that class fail quality control miserably to start with. I’d argue quality went up without eecs16b.
<md>^Agreed. The quality of CS education definitely went up now that we dropped off the deadweight in EE16B.</md>

I personally enjoyed 16B and learned a lot from it. But I also understand what you are saying here, and I just wish that there is a better way to make the classes have better quality and at thesame time ensure each students have solid knowledge ground when they left school. Other schools like CMU still also enforce many other requirements such as multival calculus... (Although I agree they don't have something like 16B which enforces the EE content for CS students)

Re: 53. This class was never required to start with. I find it weird that students used to have to option to use a lower div class that most people who got into Berkeley took in high school to fulfill upper division major requirement.

The EECS major (not LSCS) still requires Math 53. And I think it's beyond the level of high school rigorousness, and it's also required for Math major which can't be fulfilled by AP / high school credit. The main thing is that some contents from Math 53 are really useful for anything ML related in the CS domain, and while they can be self-learned, I think it's still important to have this foundational knowledge? We require linear algebra classes but at the same time doesn't require multivar calculus, despite they are both highly useful in upper-div classes, such as 189 and especially 182. I think students will easily get confused if they don't have Math 53 background and went into CS 182 and/or CS 189.

No one's saying you can't take 53. The point is choice. I and many other L&S CS majors have no need for it - I have no interest in 189 or 182, so why bother? This is what explicitly listed prereqs are for.

<md>Thank you for your interest in this!  The EECS faculty had a robust discussion of the proposal and ultimately voted in favor of removing the 16B requirement for the L&S CS major.  We listen closely to feedback from students, which you can provide in a number of ways, for instance through the annual survey run by student organizations, by working with student organizations to make your voice heard, or by sending email directly to the chairs or Vice Chairs for Undergraduate Matters.</md>

Does EECS faculty worry about this would undermine the quality and weight of LS CS education at UC Berkeley?

@17139

Since the EECS 16B change is effective starting this fall, the APR will update starting this fall. I'm working with the Central Evaluation Unit to make both the EECS 16B and tech elective changes, but they won't be active until the fall and summer, respectively.

If you're graduating in Fall 22 or later, you do not need to take EECS 16B.

<md>Thank you so much for all your work Lydia! We as CS students deeply appreciate everything you've done for us. I just have one more concern regarding the APR for CS major requirements.

I enrolled in CS168 for next semester to satisfy the L&S CS 4-unit design requirement (https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs-upperdiv), but it hasn't yet shown up in my Academic Progress Report under upper-division Design requirement. I suspect it's because the course hasn't been offered for a while and thus the system needs to be updated to include it under design. Would be great if you could also help fix this bug for CS168, as I need this requirement to graduate next semester. Thanks so much again in advance.</md>
<md>I've posted this previously here @16905, but it didn't receive any responses.</md>
Thanks for the reminder! I will ask the APR team to make this update for CS168. Please allow a couple weeks for it to update as design in the APR.
<md>Thank you!!</md>
Similarly, it seems that CS182 is not listed in the APR as a design course. Could you also remind them to make this update in the system? Thanks!
Shoot. Will do, thanks.

On my Academic Requirements page on CalCentral it still says I need to take EE16B to graduate with LSCS... My expected term of graduation is Spring 2023, though I might consider graduating Fall 2022. Do I need to stay enrolled in EE16B for the summer?
You need a minimum of 4 units, so 2 3-unit approved classes is fine.

<md>> The tech elective must be upper division and at least 4 units; students will no longer be able to petition to use Math 53 toward tech elective units.

Could you explain the meaning of this then? I also have multiple 3 unit classes including 53 that I’m using to satisfy this requirement.</md>

Basically, in the past Math 53 reduced the tech electives from 7 to 4. Now it is being reduced from 7 to 4 without having to take Math 53. Math 53 will not count toward the 4 units still required.

Could you include the multiple 3 unit classes you are using for the tech electives so I can make sure it will work?
Info 253B and Demog 180
Info 253A and Info 253B were the two classes in addition to Math 53. I have a lot of time left here so I don't mind taking more CS upper-division courses if I have to.

Demog 180 is 4 units and Info 253B is 3 units. You could either take only Demog 180 or Info 253B plus another approved tech elective for 3 units or more.


Info 253A is 3 units and Info 253B is 3 units. This would give you 6 tech elective units, which is 2 more than you need, so this is OK.

Hmm that seems to contradict the post, perhaps it should be edited for clarity since the original post makes multiple references to "4-unit course" and that "The tech elective must be upper division and at least 4 units" which confused me (I have only taken 3 unit courses outside of CS, some of which are graduate and not upper division , so I would need more CS upperdivs if this was true).

I can see it could be confusing for current students who already took a 3-unit tech elective, but future students are most likely to take one 4-unit course. We're working on updating our website and will have an FAQ addressing this question.
If I was admitted prior to Spring 2022, for the technical electives, do I absolutely need to take only 1 4-unit class or can 2 3-unit classes also work?

<md>You don't have to take 16B anymore if you did either Math 54 or 16A. If you haven't yet taken Math 54 or 16A, would highly recommend taking Math 54 instead of the EE16 series if you want a strong foundation in linear algebra and differential equations.</md>
I’ve taken 16a and am interested in the topics of 16b, with this in mind if I take 16b this fall would I still have to take math 54?
<md>No</md>
If you mean for double majoring, this is a question for DS/Math/Stat advisors? I believe you can still take 16a + 16b instead of 54 if you're a CS double.
Can we still take 16b to fulfill linear algebra requirement if we’ve take 16a?

This change goes into effect this summer. It is for students graduating Summer 2022 and later. 

If you've already taken a 4-unit approved tech elective, you don't need the 3 unit one this fall.

<md>> **Effective Summer 2022**, the number of units for the upper division technical elective requirement is reduced from 7 units to 4 units.

Does this apply to all students who are graduating after Summer 2022?

If my Fall 2022 schedule contains 3 technical elective units and I've already taken 4 technical elective units would it be prudent to change those 3 units to a different class?</md>

<md>I think advisors recommending Math 54 instead of EECS 16A to L&S CS students who show interest in more ML leaning classes is a good way to fix the important issue that Mingyang presented

But for those who arent aware, usually prereqs aren't enforced for EE/CS classes (CS 170 is the only exception I can think of).</md>
<md>^Agree with Rahul. Math 54 alone is arguably a much better foundational prep course than 16A+16B combined, for those planning on taking linear algebra heavy CS upper divs.</md>

Linear Algebra heavy upper division EE/CS classes like EECS 127 and CS 189 accept Math 54 or {EECS 16A + 16B} for their linear algebra prerequisite. As a result, a decent amount of CS majors who took EECS 16A are probably going to have to take EECS 16B or Math 54 afterwards anyway, and I worry that this may become a point of confusion of the future.
<md>You're done then. Move on to upper divs.</md>
Nothing is changing with the Math 54 or EECS 16A requirement; only EECS 16B is being removed. You can choose to take Math 54 OR EECS 16A to fulfill the linear algebra requirement.
If I have taken MATH 54 already, what is the next course I need to take to complete the linear algebra/circuitry requirement for the CS major? EECS 16A or EECS 47D or nothing?
<md>We as a department are suffering from the budget crisis, so limiting the number of enrollments in CS courses serves as a step towards alleviating the crisis. </md>

<md>The faculty considered a number of arguments, both pro and con.  I imagine this change will encourage CS majors to seek greater breadth outside of CS, and it will help us to increase the number of students we can support in the CS major and better meet the demand to major in CS.</md>

Thanks!! I definitely understand why this proposal is popular, and even necessary considering the current funding situation. I just wish there is a better way in resolving these issues, while still let students learn as much as possible, for example, there are definitely flaws in 16B's design, but we can't diminish the fact that it still conveys lots of important knowledge, which are important to both EE, ML, and DS. Many other top-tier universities also don't have a circuit / EE requirement for CS major, but they compensate by adding multivar calculus as a requirement, or by requring more CS upper divs as graduation requirements (I think 5 classes is really too few). 

As a "university", and especially a very good one, like UC Berkeley, we are not a coding bootcamp school, but an institution that provides degree in Computer "Science". There are certain foundational things that must be required for the degree, and there are certain number of upper div courses that must also be required, and not just let student have a complete/absolute freedom in choosing. Otherwise, while motivated students will still pursue more classes, many students would just choose the "easy" route and graduate from Berkeley with less knowledge. This may even be unfair to students who still opt to choose to take more (perhaps more difficult) classes, because they may have a lower GPA despite being motivated and learned more, compared to students whol chose the "easy" route to graduate, and both of them still earns the same degree..

While one can argue that we still have the freedom to choose, however I think the design of a degree program should still strictly and explicitly specify what courses must be taken, in order to ensure the rigouressness of education for all students graduating from our school? Personally, I strongly support not requiring certain upper div as requirement, because this allows students to freely explore different fields in CS.

However, I persoanally feel that, it would be better for students if we can require Math 53 as a requirement, and condense the lineal algebra materials from both 16A and 16B to a single class, and make that a requirement. While we already have Math 54, I feel the engineering approach to linear algebra, as presented in 16A and 16B, is better for CS students. And also, maybe we can require 6 upper div CS/EE/EECS/DS classes as graduating requirement instead of just 5, and have one upper div technical elective that must not be CS/EE/EECS/DS departments? I understand this may be impossible given our current financial situation, but I sincerely hope things will be better if the dept.'s financial health improved in the future.

<md>Agree with Professor Wagner. Again, every choice and decision has opportunity costs, but the decisions that our department has made here minimizes potential costs by leaving the flexibility and choice to the students, as well as saving the crucial budget needed to maintain the ongoing operation of our classes.

CS170 is a great example of how there's little need for the department to force students into taking classes that are truly considered fundamental and relevant. Most, if not all CS students would consider CS170 to be a fundamental class towards their CS education, and almost everyone would agree that it's much more important and relevant than EE16B or even Math 53. After all, algorithms and the theory of computation are the roots and origins of CS, and has many useful engineering applications in the industry. Surprisingly, CS170 isn't a graduation requirement for CS majors, but every single CS student I know have elected to take CS170 knowing how important and relevant it is to their careers and their CS education. 

If even a critical class like CS170 isn't a graduation requirement for L&S CS majors, there is very little reason to keep other classes like EE16B as a mandatory requirement. Otherwise, there will eventually be little to no freedom for our students to construct their own unique paths and careers in the broad field of CS, not to mention that the L&S College itself values flexibility and choice for our students.</md>
To clarify: current students may use a CS upper div to fulfill the tech elective requirement. Students starting Fall 22 and later must use an approved non-CS tech elective.
I am confused why one can't use a CS course to fulfill the tech elective...
Yes per @17157_f5
Just to clarify, would taking a 3 unit class (stat133) and 2 unit class (cs194-177) satisfy the new upper division technical elective requirement? (assuming I am admitted spring 2022 or before)
<md>I also have this question!</md>
Just got reply that 16B would be waived, which is consistent with this policy change.

I hope it’s not too late to ask this (‘cause I didn’t realize this problem before discussion with my friends), but would the honor application requirements for LSCS waive 16B per this change? If so, is it effective su22?

history.content:
Dear L&S Computer Science Majors,

I am writing to inform you of curriculum revisions to the L&S Computer Science major. These changes have been approved by the EECS Department and the L&S Executive Committee.

Effective Fall 2022, the EECS 16B requirement will be removed from the L&S CS curriculum. All students with graduation terms of Fall 2022 or later will not be required to complete EECS 16B. This change applies to new and continuing students.

Effective Summer 2022, the number of units for the upper division technical elective requirement is reduced from 7 units to 4 units.

  • Students admitted to UC Berkeley Fall 2022 or later may not fulfill their technical elective requirement using a CS course. They may take any other 4-unit course from the approved tech elective list. 

  • Students admitted Spring 2022 or before may fulfill the 4 units by CS/EE upper division courses or by our approved courses outside the department. The tech elective must be upper division and at least 4 units; students will no longer be able to petition to use Math 53 toward tech elective units. 

We are here to assist you with your advising needs. Should you have questions about your specific case please email cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu or book an appointment.

Sincerely,

Antoine Davis

Director, Undergraduate Affairs and Advising 
EECS Department 
#pin
history.subject: Announcement: L&S Computer Science Major Requirements Update
